results.title: Generation
results.brief_description: This documentary film is about four young teenagers who live in and around Manchester, England. It’s about their lives, their dreams, their aspirations, their alienation, their boredom, their hopelessness and their Saturday nights. Best friends, Fiona Ball and Gaynor McNulty (both aged 17) live in a small village about 40 minutes North East of Manchester. Clubbing for them is the ultimate ritual and the perfect antidote for surviving life in a small town. John McDonald (aged 15) lives on a housing estate in Stockport with his sister (aged 27) and her two young boys. For all of his tough exterior, John is extremely vulnerable and weighed down by feelings of uncertainty and apathy regarding his own future. Hussein Al-Allak (aged 15) lives alone with his mum on a housing estate in suburban Chorlton-Cum-Hardy. In contrast to John, Hussein has a sense of hope and excitement about his future. From these four stories is woven an evocative tableau of life in a northern English city. Includes information sheet. (Awards: Includes Chicago Film Festival, 1997; British Short Film Festival, 1997)

results.title: Gate
results.brief_description: Over the duration of a smoko, 3 sheep station workers (Joel Edgerton, Tony Ryan and Brett Wood) deliberate over which one of them left the gate open and allowed 800 sheep to escape. With remarkable ingenuity and careful questioning, they get to the bottom of the matter.

results.title: Fly Peewee, Fly!
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boy, Robbie is in the midst of the conflict between his father and his grandmother. Robbie’s grandmother is white and wants to give Robbie every advantage, while Robbie’s aboriginal father is searching for his own identity and place. A warm story about fragile but meaningful family relationships.

results.title: Five ninths
results.brief_description: An animated intergalactic battle crossed with an earthbound battle between a cat, a blender and a tractor. Will they all meet in the end?
results.description: An animated intergalactic battle crossed with an earthbound battle between a cat, a blender and a tractor. Will they all meet in the end?

results.title: Grace
results.brief_description: Returning from her adopted home in London, to attend the funeral of her sister, an Aboriginal woman finds herself isolated from both kin and culture. This emotionally mature and complex work moves beyond didactism and easily digestable polemics to suggest that cultural dislocation is written as much in the body, in language and the psyche as it is in economics and politics. By suggesting that the effects for the “stolen generation” were as destructive for inter-Aboriginal relationships as they were for black and white relations in this country, “Grace” is a devastating and confronting exploration of what it means to have been “stolen”.

results.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_primary.name: Brilliant careers (Gillian Armstrong)
constellations_primary.description: Gillian Armstrong's feature film debut not only helped launch her own acclaimed career, but those of the actors as well.

results.description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).
description_for_label: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama, Gillian Armstrong’s work often features female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors as well as her groundbreaking debut My Brilliant Career (1979).

results.title: Untitled Goose Game sketchbook: Stuart Gillespie-Cook
results.credit_line:
Gift of House House Pty Ltd.
Acquired via the National videogame collecting partnership between ACMI, the Powerhouse and the National Film and Sound Archive.
results.brief_description: A selection of drawings, sketches and notes from Stuart Gillespie-Cook’s sketchbook made while he was co-creating the videogame Untitled Goose Game with House House.
